articles.title: About Our Meetup
articles.description: A short history of the CEHD Tidy Tuesday meetup
articles.contents: The CEHD Tidy Tuesday meetup was the brainchild of several graduate students, post-docs, and personnel from the Institute of Child Development at the University of Minnesota. With a little support and encouragement from Andy, this group starting meeting regularly during the 2020–21 academic year. (Fun Fact: We met Thursdays, so I guess it was more of a Tidy Thursday!) We decided to expand the community to all of the CEHD graduate students in Spring of 2022.

articles.title: Getting Started at Tidy Tuesday
articles.description: A quick start guide to getting into the spirit of Tidy Tuesday
articles.contents:
Each Monday the Tidy Tuesday Social Data Project releases a dataset which is available in the R4Data Science Tidy Tuesday GitHUb repository. (You can also access older data sets here if you aren’t interested in the current one.)
Click the link for the data you want to work with. This will open a page which will give you information about the dataset(s) related to the topic (e.g., source, background), access to a data dictionary, and the R syntax for importing the data. (Note there is often a cleaning script provided that was used to take the messy raw data and clean it. The data you import from the site is already cleaned using this script, but it is sometimes interesting to see how the data were cleaned.)
What Do I Do Now that I Imported the Data?
The answer to this question is: it is up to you. The stated goal of the Tidy Tuesday Social Data Project is:

“…to provide a safe and supportive forum for individuals to practice their wrangling and data visualization skills independent of drawing conclusions.”

You could create a visualization of the data. Maybe you always wanted to try making a waffle plot. Or perhaps you want to see how to make an interactive plot using the {plotly} package. Maybe you’ve always wanted to learn how to make a map but just haven’t taken the time. Or you want to see how to animate a series of plots. Your options are limitless!



Figure 1: Hexbin map created by Twitter user @danoehm for the January 11, 2022 Bee Colony Losses data.






Figure 2: Bar chart created by Twitter user @ryanahart for the January 11, 2022 Bee Colony Losses data.






Figure 3: Jittered time plot created by Twitter user @efranke7282 for the January 11, 2022 Bee Colony Losses data.



There is no requirement that you have to do anything fancy either. Maybe you want to practice making histograms or density plots. Or just learn how to change the font used in your plots. Add titles, subtitles, footnotes. Create your own theme or color palette.



Figure 4: Twitter user @Andy_A_Baker rocked a pink background and colored text in the title in creating this scatterplot for the July 27, 2021 Olympic Medals data.



You don’t even have to create a visualization. You can practice your data wrangling; filtering, grouping, and the like. You could learn how to produce tables for your reports. Or try an alternative method than you usually use (kable? pander? gt table?) How about learning how to embed plots in a table?



Figure 5: Summary table created by Twitter user @leeolney3 for the January 18, 2022 Chocolate Bar Ratings data.



You can also get inspiration from the larger Tidy Tuesday community. Many people post their product (and code) to Twitter (search #TidyTuesday or #RStats).
Sharing My Work
Sharing your work not gives you the chance to say to others…“Hey! Check out what I did!”, but it also gives you a chance to document your own growth and learning over time. It can also serve as an inspiration to others and promotes a culture of sharing and encouragement.
Share your work with our community at the end of the meetup.
Even if you think it isn’t very good, sharing helps encourage others. It is awesome for others to see what you created. We learn and grow from seeing other people’s products.
Post your viz or table or whatever you create to Twitter.
Use the hashtag #TidyTuesday. Also, try to include a link to the code used to create your visualization when you post to Twitter. Comment your code wherever possible to help yourself and others understand your process! Also, give credit to the original data source whenever possible. Finally, don’t forget to add alt text (alternative text) to all of your posted graphics to make them more friendly for people who are visually impaired. Guidelines for how to add alt text to your images on Twitter are here.
Showcase your work on your personal website.
You could also write up a post explaining your thought process or how you did something in R.

articles.title: CEHD Tidy Tuesday Meetup
articles.contents:
Welcome to the CEHD Tidy Tuesday graduate student meetup page! Inspired by the Tidy Tuesday Social Data Project, the goal of this meetup is to promote participants’ computational skills, especially those for working with data. At the meetup, we work with data from the Tidy Tuesday project to practice and improve our techniques for visualizing and working with raw data, while leveraging the community aspect of the group to learn from each other.

Join us Spring 2022 every Tuesday from 4:00 PM –5:30 in Bruininks Hall (Room 123)!

articles.title: Resources
articles.description: Some links to resources, packages, and other fun stuff
articles.contents:
Official Tidy Tuesday Links
GitHub Repo of Data
Weekly Podcast
ggplot Functionality
Text
geomtextpath: Create curved text in ggplot2
ggtext: Add color, different fonts, etc to your ggplot axes and titles
Pictures
emoGG: Add emogi to your ggplot
ggbernie: Add Bernie Sanders to your ggplot
ggandy: Add Andy to your ggplot
Other
ggside: Create marginal distribution side plots
Tables
gtsummary: Elegant and flexible way to create publication-ready analytical and summary tables
R Markdown
bookdown: Write books using R Markdown
gopherdown: Use R Markdown to write a UMN formatted thesis
distill: Create a blog/website using R Markdown
blogdown: Hugo-based blog using R Markdown
Alison Hill’s YouTube videos for creating a website using R Markdown
GitHub
Happy Git with R
Fun with R
OregonTrail: PLay Oregon Trail in your R Console
